dom-csspseudoelement-element.name: element
dom-csspseudoelement-element.summary: The element read-only property of the CSSPseudoElement interface returns a reference to the originating element of the pseudo-element, in other words its parent element.
dom-csspseudoelement-element.title: CSSPseudoElement.element

dom-csspseudoelement-type.name: type
dom-csspseudoelement-type.summary: The type read-only property of the CSSPseudoElement interface returns the type of the pseudo-element as a string, represented in the form of a CSS selector.
dom-csspseudoelement-type.title: CSSPseudoElement.type

CSSPseudoElement-interface.name: CSSPseudoElement
CSSPseudoElement-interface.summary: The CSSPseudoElement interface represents a pseudo-element that may be the target of an event or animated using the Web Animations API. Instances of this interface may be obtained by calling Element.pseudo().
CSSPseudoElement-interface.title: CSSPseudoElement

generated-content.name: after
generated-content.summary: In CSS, ::after creates a pseudo-element that is the last child of the selected element. It is often used to add cosmetic content to an element with the content property. It is inline by default.

notes: Before Firefox 57, Firefox had a bug where ::after pseudo-elements were still generated, even if the content property value were set to normal or none.
Before Firefox 3.5, only the CSS level 2 behavior of :after was supported, which disallowed position, float, list-style-* and some display properties.
Before Firefox 57, Firefox had a bug where ::after pseudo-elements were still generated, even if the content property value were set to normal or none.
Before Firefox 3.5, only the CSS level 2 behavior of :after was supported, which disallowed position, float, list-style-* and some display properties.

generated-content.title: ::after (:after)

generated-content.name: before
generated-content.summary: In CSS, ::before creates a pseudo-element that is the first child of the selected element. It is often used to add cosmetic content to an element with the content property. It is inline by default.

notes: Before Firefox 57, Firefox had a bug where ::before pseudo-elements were still generated, even if the content property value were set to normal or none.
Before Firefox 3.5, only the CSS level 2 behavior of :before was supported, which disallowed position, float, list-style-* and some display properties.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 57, Firefox had a bug where ::before pseudo-elements were still generated, even if the content property value were set to normal or none.

generated-content.title: ::before (:before)

file-selector-button-pseudo.name: file-selector-button
file-selector-button-pseudo.summary: The ::file-selector-button CSS pseudo-element represents the button of an <input> of type="file".
file-selector-button-pseudo.title: ::file-selector-button

first-letter-pseudo.name: first-letter
first-letter-pseudo.summary: The ::first-letter CSS pseudo-element applies styles to the first letter of the first line of a block-level element, but only when not preceded by other content (such as images or inline tables).
first-letter-pseudo.title: ::first-letter (:first-letter)

first-line-pseudo.name: first-line
first-line-pseudo.summary: The ::first-line CSS pseudo-element applies styles to the first line of a block-level element.

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.
Before Chrome 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.

chrome_android.notes: Before Chrome 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.
Before Chrome 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.

opera.notes: From Opera 15 to Opera 49 (exclusive), the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.
From Opera 15 to Opera 49 (exclusive), the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.

opera_android.notes: From Opera 15 to Opera 49 (exclusive), the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.
From Opera 15 to Opera 49 (exclusive), the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.

safari.notes: The text-transform property does not work for ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See WebKit bug 3409.
The text-transform property does not work for ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See WebKit bug 3409.

safari_ios.notes: The text-transform property does not work for ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See WebKit bug 3409.
The text-transform property does not work for ::first-line or :first-line pseudo-elements. See WebKit bug 3409.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Before Samsung Internet 8.0, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.
Before Samsung Internet 8.0, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.

webview_android.notes: Before WebView 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.
Before WebView 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.

edge_blink.notes: Before Chrome 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.
Before Chrome 62, the text-transform property does not work on ::first-line pseudo-elements. See Chromium bug 129669.

first-line-pseudo.title: ::first-line (:first-line)

selectordef-grammar-error.name: grammar-error
selectordef-grammar-error.summary: The ::grammar-error CSS pseudo-element represents a text segment which the user agent has flagged as grammatically incorrect.
selectordef-grammar-error.title: ::grammar-error

marker-pseudo.name: marker
marker-pseudo.summary: The ::marker CSS pseudo-element selects the marker box of a list item, which typically contains a bullet or number. It works on any element or pseudo-element set to display: list-item, such as the <li> and <summary> elements.

safari.notes: Safari support is limited to color and font-size. See bug 204163.

safari_ios.notes: Safari support is limited to color and font-size. See bug 204163.

marker-pseudo.title: ::marker

placeholder-pseudo.name: placeholder
placeholder-pseudo.summary: The ::placeholder CSS pseudo-element represents the placeholder text in an <input> or <textarea> element.
placeholder-pseudo.title: ::placeholder

selectordef-selection.name: selection
selectordef-selection.summary: The ::selection CSS pseudo-element applies styles to the part of a document that has been highlighted by the user (such as clicking and dragging the mouse across text).
selectordef-selection.title: ::selection

selectordef-spelling-error.name: spelling-error
selectordef-spelling-error.summary: The ::spelling-error CSS pseudo-element represents a text segment which the user agent has flagged as incorrectly spelled.
selectordef-spelling-error.title: ::spelling-error

selectordef-target-text.name: target-text
selectordef-target-text.summary: The ::target-text CSS pseudo-element represents the text that has been scrolled to if the browser supports scroll-to-text fragments. It allows authors to choose how to highlight that section of text.
selectordef-target-text.title: ::target-text
